definition: Qualitative platelet defect in advanced kidney failure due to circulating uremic toxins and altered nitric oxide or prostacyclin balance. Causes impaired adhesion and aggregation with normal platelet count.

images.alt: Uremia causing qualitative platelet dysfunction with normal count

why_it_matters: Common, under-recognized cause of mucosal bleeding in renal failure. Peri-procedural planning and rapid reversal options are frequently tested.
how_youll_see_it: Patients with ESRD or severe AKI with epistaxis, easy bruising, or oozing from access sites.
Labs: platelet count normal; bleeding time prolonged; PT and PTT usually normal.
History of missed dialysis or uremic symptoms such as nausea, pericarditis, or pruritus.
problem_solving: Best treatment is dialysis to reduce uremic toxins.
For urgent procedures or active bleeding: give desmopressin to raise endogenous vWF; consider cryoprecipitate.
Correct anemia; raising hematocrit improves platelet function. Avoid antiplatelet drugs when possible.

differentials.hint: inherited adhesion defect; not limited to renal failure

differentials.name: Disseminated intravascular coagulation
differentials.hint: abnormal PT or PTT with low fibrinogen and high D-dimer

tricks: Normal platelet count with prolonged bleeding time in a dialysis patient points to uremic dysfunction.
Desmopressin works within hours by releasing vWF from endothelium.
exam_appearance: ESRD patient with oozing from fistula site and normal platelet count before an urgent procedure; receives desmopressin.
Missed dialysis session followed by epistaxis and prolonged bleeding time that improves after dialysis.
treatment: Desmopressin for rapid hemostasis; add cryoprecipitate if refractory.
Optimize hematocrit; avoid or hold antiplatelet drugs when safe.
red_flags: Life-threatening hemorrhage requires urgent dialysis plus pharmacologic hemostasis.
Consider alternative causes if PT or PTT are prolonged or if platelet count is low.
algorithm: Renal failure patient with mucocutaneous bleeding -> check platelet count and coagulation tests.
If platelet count normal and PT and PTT normal but bleeding time prolonged -> uremic dysfunction likely.
Treat with dialysis and desmopressin; plan peri-procedural prophylaxis.

cases.stem: A patient with ESRD scheduled for emergent central line placement is oozing from access sites.
cases.teaching: Give desmopressin for rapid effect and arrange dialysis.

cases.stem: A man with missed dialysis presents with nosebleeds.
cases.teaching: Bleeding improves after dialysis; correct anemia to improve platelet function.
